species from lit review: Schistosoma mansoni, Schistosoma haematobium, Schistosoma japonicum, Schistosoma intercalatum, Schistosoma mekongi, Schistosoma guineensis, Schistosoma malayensis
mode of transmission: Contaminated water with intermediate snail hosts
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhea, bloody stool, blood in the urine, liver damage, kidney failure, infertility, bladder cancer, poor growth and learning difficulty in children

dalys: 1363952.52 (other sources say as many as 5.09 million - this includes depressive illnesses)
mode of transmission: Mosquito bites
associated symptoms: Lymphedema, hydrocele, elephantiasis, tropical pulmonary eosinophilia syndrome (but most people are asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Contact with feces of an infected individual
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain, cough, diarrhea, fatigue, fever, gas, itchy rash, loss of appetite, nausea and/or vomiting, pale skin

species from lit review: Fasciola hepatica, Opisthorchis viverrini, Fasciola gigantica, Clonorchis sinensis, Opisthorchis felineus, Paragonimus westermani, Paragonimus skrjabini, Echinostoma revolutum, Fasciolopsis buski
mode of transmission: Eating infected fish, plants, or crustaceans
number infected: Lots of conflicting answers on this
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain, gall bladder inflammation and fibrosis, liver fibrosis, colic pain, jaundice, anemia, cough, chest pain, shortness of breath, fever

mode of transmission: Ingesting eggs from feces of an infected individual
associated symptoms: Abdominal discomfort, cough, intestinal blockage, impaired growth in children (most people are asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Ingesting eggs from feces of an infected individual
associated symptoms: Diarrhea, bloody stool, rectal prolapse, anemia, impaired growth in children

mode of transmission: Blackfly bites
associated symptoms: Blindness, visual impairment, nodules under the skin and/or debilitating itching
treatment options: Anti-helminthics (ivermectin to kill larvae and doxycycline to kill adult worms)

mode of transmission: Deerfly bites
associated symptoms: Calabar swellings, eye worm, hives, muscle pain, joint pain, tiredness (most people are asymptomatic)

deaths: 749.15 (though other sources say 50000 - why is the GBD value so low?)
dalys: 1608143.55 (other sources say as high as 2.8 million)
mode of transmission: Ingesting eggs from feces of an infected individual
associated symptoms: Cysts in the muscles, eyes, or central nervous system; seizures; headaches

mode of transmission: Mosquito bites
associated symptoms: Inflammation in pulmonary arteries, cough, chest pain, fever, pleural effusion (most people asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Ingesting food items contaminated with stool from foxes or coyotes, petting or handling household dogs or cats infected with the Echinococcus multilocularis tapeworm
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain or discomfort, weakness, weight loss

mode of transmission: Ingesting food, water, or soil contaminated with stool from infected dogs
number infected: 1 million (don't know how accurate this is)
associated symptoms: Discomfort, pain, nausea, vomiting, anaphylactic reactions
treatment options: Chemotherapy, cyst puncture, PAIR (percutaneous aspiration, injection of chemicals and reaspiration), surgery

deaths: 50000 deaths annually from CNS or cardiac complications
mode of transmission: Ingesting raw or undercooked beef or pork
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain, loss of appetite, weight loss, upset stomach (most people are asymptomatic)

species from lit review: Mansonella perstans, Mansonella ozzardi, Mansonella streptocerca
mode of transmission: Blackfly bites
associated symptoms: Angioedema, pruritus, fever, headaches, arthralgias, adenopathy, hepatomegaly, pulmonary symptoms, swelling, eosinophilia, hives, hydrocele, and neurologic manifestations (most people are asymptomatic)
treatment options: Anti-helminthics (diethylcarbamazine, mebendazole), though these have limited effectiveness

mode of transmission: Mosquito bites
associated symptoms: Nodules under the skin and under the conjunctiva of the eye (most people are asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Contaminated water
associated symptoms: Fever, swelling, and pain at the site where the worm exits the skin, which often develops a secondary bacterial infection

mode of transmission: Contact with soil containin free-living larvae
number infected: 30-100 million (though another source says up to 370 million)
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain, bloating, heartburn, intermittent episodes of diarrhea and constipation, a dry cough, and skin rashes (most people are asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Ingesting raw or undercooked snails or slugs
associated symptoms: Symptoms of bacterial meningitis, such as nausea, vomiting, neck stiffness, and headaches

mode of transmission: Ingesting dirt containing infected dog or cat feces
associated symptoms: Fever, coughing, enlarged liver, pneumonia, ocular toxocariasis (most people are asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Ingesting infected ants
associated symptoms: Cholecystitis, liver abscesses, and generalized gastrointestinal/abdominal distress

mode of transmission: Ingesting infected arthropods, soil, or contaminated feces
associated symptoms: Nausea, weakness, loss of appetite, diarrhea, and abdominal pain (most people are asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Fly bites
associated symptoms: Watery eyes, conjunctivitis, corneal opacity, or corneal ulcers (most people are asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Ingesting raw or undercooked beef or pork
associated symptoms: Nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, muscle pain, fever, swelling of the eyes, weakness or fatigue, headache, chills, itchy skin or rash, cough, constipation

mode of transmission: Ingesting raw or undercooked fish or squid
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, diarrhea, blood and mucus in stool, mild fever, rash, itching

mode of transmission: Ingesting infected arthropods
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain, itching, irritability, eosinophilia (most people are asymptomatic)

mode of transmission: Oral-fecal (though this is contested)
associated symptoms: Abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, low-grade fever, protruding abdominal masses, intestinal obstruction
